label: [I2C] Scroll pHAT
info: ::: aim To control a [Scroll pHAT](https://github.com/pimoroni/scroll-phat) board from [Pimoroni](https://learn.pimoroni.com/). The idea is to use the [i2c bus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/I%C2%B2C) to control the board. The Scroll pHAT board being used is the simplest 5 by 11 LED with a single brightness setting for all pixels. ::: ::: palette - [node-red-contrib-i2c](https://flows.nodered.org/node/node-red-contrib-i2c) - [node-red-dashboard](https://flows.nodered.org/node/node-red-dashboard) ::: ### Requirements There are several descriptions on setting up the i2c bus on a Raspberry Pi: - [i2c-bus documentation ay i2c-bus package](https://github.com/fivdi/i2c-bus/blob/master/doc/raspberry-pi-i2c.md) - [the install script for the Scroll pHAT](https://get.pimoroni.com/scrollphat) was helpful I used a Raspberry Pi Model 4 for doing this, your mileage might vary. ### Background The details of the device can be obtained from the [driver](https://github.com/pimoroni/scroll-phat/blob/5a0a47f6e4faac649d89054135baa542889ff3fa/library/scrollphat/IS31FL3730.py#L5-L8) code: ``` self.I2C_ADDR = 0x60 self.CMD_SET_MODE = 0x00 self.CMD_SET_BRIGHTNESS = 0x19 self.MODE_5X11 = 0b00000011 ``` And this [line](https://github.com/pimoroni/scroll-phat/blob/5a0a47f6e4faac649d89054135baa542889ff3fa/library/scrollphat/IS31FL3730.py#L55) that gives the cmd (i.e., 0x01) for setting the pixels: ``` self.bus.write_i2c_block_data(self.i2cConstants.I2C_ADDR, 0x01, self.window) ``` Also each update of the pixels needs to end with [0xff](https://github.com/pimoroni/scroll-phat/blob/5a0a47f6e4faac649d89054135baa542889ff3fa/library/scrollphat/IS31FL3730.py#L52). Since the device has no state, every update of the pixels needs to update all pixels. This then becomes an array of 11 columns plus 0xff as terminator, meaning that each update must be an array of [12 bytes](https://github.com/pimoroni/scroll-phat/blob/5a0a47f6e4faac649d89054135baa542889ff3fa/library/scrollphat/IS31FL3730.py#L55). A column can be represented by an array of five entries, one each for the row. These are converted to a byte value using their binary representation: ``` row1 - off row2 - on row3 - off row4 - on row5 - off ==> - 0b01010 ==> 10 ``` This means that an array of: ``` [10,10,10,10,10, 10,10,10,10,10, 10, 255] ``` would light up rows two and four (with 255 being the 0xff terminator). ### Flow explanation The mode (which has to be 3) can be set with the mode group and the brightness (anything above zero) can be set with this group. The reset group can be used to turn all leds on or off. There is a dashboard for toggling each led on or off and this dashboard is defined by the toggle switch group that is order as the LEDs on the Scroll pHAT. The logic group does a number of things: - ignore the messages that reset the board (switch) - convert the `topic` that contains the location of the toggle to column and row values (change node) - buffer multiple messages into a single array of updates. This prevents sending too many updates to the device but adds an delay of a second to the display update (join node) - compute the current board configuration and store the state into the flow, create an array of the i2c bus. (function node) ### Dashboard A dashboard page is created which allows updating each pixel individually: ![img](https://cdn.openmindmap.org/content/1691327372482_Screen_Shot_2023-08-06_at_14.54.26.png) The end result of that is ![img](https://cdn.openmindmap.org/content/1691327462428_signal-2023-08-06-145626_002.jpeg)

name: allow individual pixels to be toggled
prepare data and store \n state into the flow context
[scrollphat] brightness
info:
`msg` must have a payload with a value betwenn zero and 20:

```
msg.payload = <brightness value 0 to 20>
```

where 0 is no brightness, i.e. off, and 20 is the highest brightness.

name: [scrollphat] set single pixel on or off
info:
`msg` must be of the form:

```
msg = {
    col: <column 1 to 11>,
    row: <row 1 to 5>,
    payload: <true or false - on or off>
}
```
